SEARCH
Package Datastructures.Clauses

Klasse Clause

java.lang.Object
Datastructures.Clauses.Clause
Alle implementierten Schnittstellen:
Iterable<CLiteral>, Positioned, Sizable
public class Clause extends Object implements Iterable<CLiteral>, Positioned, Sizable
A clause is primarily a list of CLiterals. OR-Clauses and ATLEAST-clauses have an addition parameter limit:
2:p,q,r means atleast 2 literals must be true in order to make the clause true.
Multiple occurrences of the same literal in a clause are represented by the parameter multiplicity in CLiterals. Created by ohlbach on 13.09.2018.

  • Konstruktorübersicht

    Konstruktoren
    Konstruktor
    Beschreibung
    Clause(int id)
    constructs a new clause
    Clause(int[] inputClause)
    generates a clause from a inputClause The constructor does not work for INTERVAL-type basic clauses.
    The new clause gets the same id as the basic clause.
    There is no semantic check.
    That means the limits must be okay (checked in BasicClauseList),
    and there msy still be multiple literals and tautologies in the clause.
    The limit of clauses where there is no limit (AND, EQUIV) is set to -1
    Atmost-clauses like atmost 2 p,q,r are transformed into atleast 1 -p,-q,-r.
    Atleast-clauses like atleast 3 p,q,r are transformed into and p,q,r
    If the limit of ATLEAST-clauses is 1,the connective is set to OR.
    Clause(int id, Quantifier quantifier, int... literals)
    creates a new clause with the given literals The constructor does not work for INTERVAL-type basic clauses.
    There is no semantic check.
    That means the limits must be okay (checked in BasicClauseList),
    and there msy still be multiple literals and tautologies in the clause.
    The limit of clauses where there is no limit (AND, EQUIV) is set to -1
    Atmost-clauses like atmost 2 p,q,r are transformed into atleast 1 -p,-q,-r.
    Atleast-clauses like atleast 3 p,q,r are transformed into and p,q,r
    If the limit of ATLEAST-clauses is 1,the connective is set to OR.
    Clause(int id, Quantifier quantifier, short minLimit, int size)
    constructs a clause with an empty list of literals.
    Clause(int id, Quantifier quantifier, short minLimit, it.unimi.dsi.fastutil.ints.IntArrayList literals)
    constructs a new clause with given literals

    setPositiveNegative()
    determines for an ATLEAST- or OR-clause the clause's structure: If the limit is too large: CONTRADICTORY
    If the limit is 0: TAUTOLOGY,
    If the limit is the clause's size then the connective is changed to AND, and the limit to -1
    otherwise if the clause has only positive literals (POSITIVE) or only negative literals (NEGATIVE) or mixed signs (MIXED)

    • Clause

      public Clause(int id)
      constructs a new clause
      Parameter:
      id - its identifier

    • Clause

      public Clause(int id, Quantifier quantifier, short minLimit, int size)
      constructs a clause with an empty list of literals.
      Parameter:
      id - the clause problemId
      minLimit - the quantification limit
      size - the estimated number of literals

    • Clause

      public Clause(int id, Quantifier quantifier, short minLimit, it.unimi.dsi.fastutil.ints.IntArrayList literals)
      constructs a new clause with given literals
      Parameter:
      id - the id of the new clause
      quantifier - the connective for the clause
      minLimit - the quantification limit
      literals - the list of literals

    • Clause

      public Clause(int[] inputClause)
      generates a clause from a inputClause The constructor does not work for INTERVAL-type basic clauses.
      The new clause gets the same id as the basic clause.
      There is no semantic check.
      That means the limits must be okay (checked in BasicClauseList),
      and there msy still be multiple literals and tautologies in the clause.
      The limit of clauses where there is no limit (AND, EQUIV) is set to -1
      Atmost-clauses like atmost 2 p,q,r are transformed into atleast 1 -p,-q,-r.
      Atleast-clauses like atleast 3 p,q,r are transformed into and p,q,r
      If the limit of ATLEAST-clauses is 1,the connective is set to OR. The clause's structure is set to POSITIVE,NEGATIVE or MIXED.
      Parameter:
      inputClause - a basic clause [id,typenumber, limit, literal1,...]

    • Clause

      public Clause(int id, Quantifier quantifier, int... literals)
      creates a new clause with the given literals The constructor does not work for INTERVAL-type basic clauses.
      There is no semantic check.
      That means the limits must be okay (checked in BasicClauseList),
      and there msy still be multiple literals and tautologies in the clause.
      The limit of clauses where there is no limit (AND, EQUIV) is set to -1
      Atmost-clauses like atmost 2 p,q,r are transformed into atleast 1 -p,-q,-r.
      Atleast-clauses like atleast 3 p,q,r are transformed into and p,q,r
      If the limit of ATLEAST-clauses is 1,the connective is set to OR. The clause's structure is set to POSITIVE,NEGATIVE or MIXED.
      Parameter:
      id - the new id
      quantifier - the clause's type (no INTERVAL-type)
      literals - [limit] a list of literals

  • Methodendetails

    • intervalClause

      public static ArrayList<Clause> intervalClause(IntSupplier nextId, int[] basicClause) throws Unsatisfiable
      Transforms an INTERVAL-clause into (usually) two ATLEAST-clauses. Example: [2,4] p,q,r,s,t -> atleast 2 p,q,r,s,t and atleast 1 -p,-q,-r,-s,-t
      Special cases are [0,m] p,... (actuall atmost m p,...)
      and [n,k] p_1,..,p_k (actually atleast n p_1,...)
      They generate only one clause.
      Parameter:
      nextId - for determinining the clause id
      basicClause - a basic interval-clause
      Gibt zurück:
      one or two new clauses
      Löst aus:
      Unsatisfiable

    • analyseSemantically

      public Clause analyseSemantically(IntSupplier nextId, ArrayList<Clause> clauses) throws Unsatisfiable
      Löst aus:
      Unsatisfiable

    • getDiophantineEquation

      private DiophantineEquation getDiophantineEquation()
      generates a constrained diophantine equation from a clause. Example: atleast 5 p^3,q^4,r,s,t -> 3*x_1+4*x_2+y = 5 where
      the x_i take 0 or 1, and y is constrained to 0 Ungültige Eingabe: "<"= y Ungültige Eingabe: "<"= 3
      If there is no solution then there is no model for the clause.
      Gibt zurück:
      the generated diophantine equation

    • getNeededLiterals

      protected Clause getNeededLiterals(int andId, DiophantineEquation eq)
      checks if the clause implies true literals. Example: atleast 4: p^2,q^2,r enforces p and q to be true in order to get enough true literals
      Parameter:
      andId - an id for the new and-clause (if negative then the clauses need not be copied)
      eq - the diophantine equation which investigated the satisfiability of the clause
      Gibt zurück:
      null or an and-clause

    • clone

      public Clause clone(int id)
      creates a clone of the clause. Only the literals themselves are cloned
      Parameter:
      id - the identifier for the new clone
      Gibt zurück:
      the new clone

    • compactify

      public void compactify()

    • toAtmost

      public Clause toAtmost(int id)
      turns an atleast-clause into an atmost-clause
      Parameter:
      id - the id for the new atmost-clause
      Gibt zurück:
      a new atmost-clause equivalent to the atleast-clause.

    • toAtleast

      public Clause toAtleast(int id)
      turns an atleast-clause into an atmost-clause
      Parameter:
      id - the id for the new atmost-clause
      Gibt zurück:
      a new atmost-clause equivalent to the atleast-clause.

    • toAnd

      public Clause toAnd(IntSupplier nextId, int sign)
      turns a clause to an AND-clause. The limit is set to a and the multiplicities are set to 1
      Parameter:
      nextId - for computing the next identifier
      sign - +1 or -1
      Gibt zurück:
      either the original clause (nextId == null) or a new AND-clause

    • toCNF

      public ArrayList<Clause> toCNF(IntSupplier nextId, boolean trackReasoning) throws Unsatisfiable
      turns an atleast-clause into conjunctive normal form
      Parameter:
      nextId - it provides the next id for the new clause
      trackReasoning - if true then a corresponding inference step is attached to the new clauses
      Gibt zurück:
      a list of OR-clauses as the conjunctive normal form of the atleast-clause
      Löst aus:
      Unsatisfiable

    • removeTrueFalseLiterals

      public Clause removeTrueFalseLiterals(IntUnaryOperator getTruthStatus, IntSupplier nextInt) throws Unsatisfiable
      replaces all true and false literals in the clause. If nextId != null then the replacements is done on a clone of the clause, otherwise on the clause itself.
      The clause may become a tautology or contradictory.
      In both cases the structure of the clause is set accordingly
      The connective of the clause is adjusted at the new situation.
      Parameter:
      getTruthStatus - maps a literal to +1 (true), 0 (undefined) or -1 (false)
      nextInt - null or a supplier for the identifier for a clone of the clause
      Gibt zurück:
      either the original changed clause or a clone.
      Löst aus:
      Unsatisfiable

    • removeComplementaryLiterals

      public Clause removeComplementaryLiterals(IntSupplier nextId) throws Unsatisfiable
      removes complementary literals from the clause. If nextId != null then the clause is cloned before the literals are removed. If the limit is reduced to 0 then the clause is marked as TAUTOLOGY
      Parameter:
      nextId - null or a supplier for clause ids
      Gibt zurück:
      the possibly shortened clause (original or clone)
      Löst aus:
      Unsatisfiable

    • splitOffMultiples

      public ArrayList<Clause> splitOffMultiples(IntSupplier nextId, boolean trackReasoning) throws Unsatisfiable
      extracts OR-Clauses from the literals with multiplicities > 1. Example: atleast 3 pp,qq,r
      Since there is only one r, atleast 2 pp,qq must hold
      This is turned into CNF and gets just p,q
      Parameter:
      nextId - for generating an id for the clauses
      Gibt zurück:
      null or a list of OR-clauses.
      Löst aus:
      Unsatisfiable

    • toArray

      public it.unimi.dsi.fastutil.ints.IntArrayList toArray()
      copies the literals of the clause to an IntArrayList
      Gibt zurück:
      the literals as IntArrayList

      public int expandedSize()
      computes the expanded size of the clause, with all multiple occurrences of literals counted
      Gibt zurück:
      the expanded size of the clause

    • setPositiveNegative

      public void setPositiveNegative()
      determines for an ATLEAST- or OR-clause the clause's structure: If the limit is too large: CONTRADICTORY
      If the limit is 0: TAUTOLOGY,
      If the limit is the clause's size then the connective is changed to AND, and the limit to -1
      otherwise if the clause has only positive literals (POSITIVE) or only negative literals (NEGATIVE) or mixed signs (MIXED)

    • removeLiteral

      public Clause removeLiteral(int literal, IntSupplier nextId, boolean truth) throws Unsatisfiable
      removes all multiplicities of the literal from the clause. If nextInt != null, a new clause is created, otherwise the removal is destructive
      Parameter:
      literal - the literal to be removed
      nextId - if != null, it provides the next id for the new clause
      truth - if true then a true literal is removed, otherwise a false literal
      Gibt zurück:
      the old or the new clause.
      Löst aus:
      Unsatisfiable

    • contains

      public int contains(int literal, CLiteral ignore)
      checks if the literal is in the clause (except cliteral)
      Parameter:
      literal - a literal
      ignore - a cLiteral to be ignored.
      Gibt zurück:
      +1: the literal is in the clause, -1: the negated literal is in the clause, otherwise 0

      public ArrayList<CLiteral> getCliterals()
